Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Palonosetron and Ondansetron for PONV Prophylaxis

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial included patients undergoing non-laparoscopic surgeries.

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial included patients undergoing non-laparoscopic surgeries.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either intravenous palonosetron or ondansetron for PONV prophylaxis.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to compare the efficacy and safety of palonosetron and ondansetron in preventing PONV in non-laparoscopic surgeries.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of nausea and vomiting at postoperative time points: 0–2 hours, 0–6 hours, 12–24 hours, 24–48 hours, and 24–72 hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 1681 participants were randomised: 842 to palonosetron and 839 to ondansetron.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The pooled risk ratio (RR) for nausea at 12–24 hours was 0.39 (95% CI: 0.16, 0.96), and for vomiting at 24–48 hours was 0.24 (95% CI: 0.09, 0.62).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild and occurred with similar frequency in both groups.
